title: If property is in probate ,do u still have to pay property tax on land.
question: Fathers decrease and we started probate procedures property taxes are due in May 2015
answers:
Yes the real property taxes are owed. If the estate has money then by all means pay the property taxes to avoid the 10% penalty. If the property is going to be sold in the probate then they will be paid by escrow from the proceeds of sale. Simply, if there is money pay it and if not do not kill yourself over a 10% penalty. Most times if you loan the money for property taxes, insurance and/or mortgage payments, they can be directly reimbursed from escrow from the proceeds of the sale rather than waiting until the end of the case. I hope this helps.

Yes. All expenses associated with property of the estate must be paid during probate process. These include, not limited to following: property taxes, mortgage, insurance, maintenance. It is responsibility of executor or personal administrator to pay these expenses. If there is not sufficient liquid assets available to pay these expenses, you probate attorney may negotiate forebearance agreements with creditors during pendency of probate.
Property taxes insurance if any, mortgage, if any. All debts of the decedent need to be paid through the probate process.

I think you meant father is deceased. But property taxes are still owed even if the property is in probate. The estate of the decedent is responsible for the taxes until an order for distribution is given and then those who inherit the property must pay the taxes.

Property taxes are due April 10. There is a 10% penalty if paid on April 11 or later.
You need to pay the property taxes. You (or whoever paid them) can be reimbursed from the estate.
Also, you need to file the Preliminary Change of Ownership form with the county tax assessor. If children inherit also file the parent-child exclusion form. If someone other than a child or spouse will inherit (niece, nephew, sister), then some part of the property will be reassessed as of the date of death and a tax bill will be sent. It may take a year before the bill is sent and, if they calculate the reassessment after a new property tax year starts, you will get 2 tax bills.
